164.67.text: The murder of the British soldier, Lee Rigby,

166.36.text: proved to be a major turning point for the English Defence League.

170.27.text:
terms of its external profile, it moved from being a fringe organisation
to a household name

177.29.text: Local divisions of the EDL reported a tripling  of registrations through the social network

185.07.text: and website pages within 48 hours of the death of Lee Rigby

194.60.text: The EDL had emerged back in 2009 in direct response to protests

198.74.text:
by the Islamist group Al-Muhajiroun to celebrations of British troops homecomings
in Luton.

206.73.text:
Those links with ex-army personnel and with some of their organisations
remain strong within the movement

214.33.text:
and at grassroots level, concerns about disrespect for British troops
remains a strong motive for participation and membership of the movement

327.86.text: The voices heard in this film are those of grassroots activists

330.36.text: it was a consant decision from the start of the research

333.40.text: to focus on everyday members of the EDL rather than the leadership,

338.45.text:
whose opinions and positions can be accessed 
by other means than ethnographic research.

343.89.text: However some of the voices you will hear in this film

345.99.text: are those of informal organisers and "admins"

351.28.text: In the film all  the names are changed

353.39.text:
to reflect the pseudonyms that the respondents have been given
 in the academic publications

357.84.text: although those who agreed to be filmed know

360.99.text: that their right to anonymity are compromised by their appearance in the film.

638.54.text: The EDL is routinely referred to in the press as a far right or extreme right group

644.05.text:
From an academic perspective it shows distinct differences from traditional
far-right and neo-Nazi groups.

650.83.text: It is closer to a social movement than a political party

654.49.text: and from leadership through to grassroots there is almosta a universal concern

660.12.text: to mark a clear line between EDL and classic ‘far right’ or neo-Nazi groups.

665.93.text: This has led some to suggest the EDL is part of a ‘new far right’

670.60.text: whose ideology is characterized by a very loose set of views focusing around

675.41.text: ‘ultra-patriotism; a critique of mainstream politics; and an aggressive, anti-Muslim agenda’.

689.51.text: From my own experience of researching at the grassroots level,

692.52.text:
I would probably go further and suggest that alligiance to either right or left
 has relatively little meaning for most members of the movement

699.85.text: and that there is little sense of a shared ideology

702.97.text: even though extreme members on the fringe of the organisation

707.40.text:
who follow some form of national socialist ideology
come from very different starting points.

1037.24.text: But does this perceprion of Islam as constituting a cultural threat to British society

1041.60.text: mean that the EDL is inherently islamophobic or racist?

1046.05.text: If there is an ideological trope underpinning  narratives of participants in this research

1052.04.text: I would say it's  less classic form of racism

1055.81.text: which is in any case overtly condemned by many participants

1060.06.text: than a kind of ‘anti-multiculturalism’ where ‘multiculturalism’ is seen as a top-down political agenda

1067.75.text: imposed without a mandate ‘from the people’.

1654.58.text: Now the people in the UK, British born people

1656.24.text: They ain’t got no jobs here, so what are you supposed to do?

1658.08.text: Obviously you have to do other stuff to support yourself

1661.33.text: It’s like myself, I used to do security, for example

1664.30.text: I used to get like 80 pound a shift

1668.67.text: Now the Sudanis, Somalians, Afghanis have come

1672.14.text: They work for two hours for 20 pound

1674.53.text:
- What do you think EDL stands for?
- English Defence League

1681.30.text:
- Yes, but what do they do?
- Stand for our rights

1689.19.text:
If you go round now, all the young kids now can’t get no jobs now
 because all the Pakis have got them.

1696.46.text: - They’re knocking people’s homes down to build mosques for people to pray in there.

1700.87.text: What you should do is shove a pig’s head on them gates, man.

1707.04.text: - Do you think a lot of people think the same way as you?

1708.97.text: - Yeah, a lot of people. They always come first.

1711.44.text:
- So why don’t people come out? There’s not many young people, are there? 
Why don’t they come out and demo?

1716.50.text: - Because they’re probably scared of like all them people coming after them.

1720.99.text: - You think they think that they would get kind of attacked if they came out, do you?

1726.45.text: - So what will you go back and say now?

1730.09.text: - Tell people that they need to come.

1735.23.text: - Do you think it’s important still to go out on the streets and demonstrate?

1737.46.text: - Yeah. Nothing wrong with it. You’ve got to fight for your own country.

1740.88.text: - Do you think it will achieve anything?

1746.18.text:
- In the future we’ll achieve something but if we go on the street now where I come from 
and we’re shouting ‘EDL’, I’d probably get jumped on.

1758.98.text: No surrender! No surrender to the Taliban.

1776.83.text: Amidst this ambiguous and diverse set of positionings

1779.43.text: what emerges clearly is that EDL members share a sense

1783.51.text: that they as white British or white English have a ‘minority’ status

1788.70.text: and are subject to discrimination in terms of access to public resources

1795.75.text:
as well as by what they call a ‘two tier’ justice system
that privileges ethnic or religious minorities.

1809.13.text: If we would have attacked, 5 of us would of attacked a Muslim

1812.67.text: it would have been affray, it would have been a racist attack

1815.09.text: and we’d have been jailed for it.

1817.25.text: There is now double standards in this country.

1819.13.text:
If you are a white, ethnic British person
and you do something like that you’re a racist.

1826.18.text: If somebody attacks you, I know there are new laws now,

1829.92.text:
which has been about 4, 5 years to say that,
a white person can be attacked and it’s a racist attack.

1843.73.text:
I was sat on the train coming over here this afternoon
about quarter past 1

1849.91.text: and I had a black African girl sat next to me which I haven’t got a problem with.

1855.82.text: But she kept, you know when the train is packed

1857.90.text: and she kept moving and her leg was shoving up against mine

1860.77.text: and she kept nudging my shoulder and, she wasn’t doing it on purpose,

1865.89.text:
if I’d have turned around and said to her
‘oh for fuck’s sake do you mean not keep doing that sort of thing it is irritating me now?’

1871.33.text: with my track record now that probably would have been deemed as racist.

1876.19.text:
- What does that make you think about British democracy?
- Crap.

1879.93.text: There isn’t any is there? It’s erm, yeah it’s not good actually.

1887.68.text: we’ve got no civil rights, you know what I mean?

1891.08.text: We’ve lost all our civil rights I feel. I don’t know, it’s a weird one.

1898.48.text: I can't wait for you to go to Luton and see what it is all about!

1901.17.text: It is unbelievable. There are hundreds and hundreds.

1905.03.text:
Police always say something like there was three hundred.
There wasn’t three hundred.

1908.47.text: There was three thousand. Do you know what I mean?

1910.58.text: But the police always say there was three hundred.

1912.65.text: I mean if you’ve got somebody standing up the road

1914.70.text: like with the camera and you can see bodies for as far as the eye can see

1920.56.text: that’s not three hundred people. They said it was three hundred people.

1924.73.text: - See that’s when you feel you are doing a cause, yeah?

1926.03.text: I mean when you’ve got three thousand people there all for the same reason,

1930.12.text: not there for throwing bricks or what not you know

1934.19.text: we are there we are marching that’s when you feel proud

- My name is Tommy and  I'm divisional leader of the
 English Defence League’s gay division

1952.45.text: and EDL have had this division for over 3 years

1954.83.text: but from the media bias you would not know this

1958.31.text: otherwise they can’t keep up with the lie that we are homophobic fascists

Even before EDL existed some of the first people to protest
against Islamisation was gay people

1977.94.text: Statistics show that 40% of this country are homophobes

1981.89.text: But look at this crowd now, I don't see a single homophobe here

1985.96.text: Otherwise I wouldn't have been allowed to speak

1991.97.text: The EDL is not about sexuality, is not about skin color, is not about religious beliefs

1997.72.text:
all that matters is that we stand as one and we fight for England
until our dying breath

2005.58.text:
There are numerous reasons why people leave,
or more usually ‘take a step back’ from the EDL.

2008.53.text:
The ones that are often cited relate to the heavy toll
 participation takes on everyday lives.

2016.18.text: I  was just walking up here and I’ve noticed the car drive past me,

2018.30.text: it’s gone up to the island up here and then it’s come back down

2021.82.text: and I’m on my phone texting somebody,

2024.44.text: I’ve seen like about four Asian people, dunno if they’re Muslim or what

2027.38.text: and they’ve gone back round to the island and they’ve come back up

2031.23.text: and I’ve looked and I’ve thought oh, here we go

2032.75.text: so I carried on walking and I was about here and they pulled up

2036.63.text: and I seen one of them on the opposite side of the car, like that,

2040.65.text: hanging out the window and I thought what’s he doing,

2042.77.text: so I carried on walking and the next minute I’ve heard like a smash,

2045.86.text: I just looked, it was round about here,

2047.90.text: just smash and I thought I could smell petrol

2050.01.text: and the car sped off and I was like there was petrol there

2052.06.text: a few bits on my jeans,  and I’ve looked and there’s like a rag in the middle of the road

2056.20.text: and it was on fire and I thought fucking hell, someone tried to petrol me

2060.17.text: I was panicking, if they come I was looking for anything like a piece of wood,

2064.69.text:
‘cause I’m thinking well they’ve just thrown a petrol bomb at me,
what are they gonna do next?

2068.24.text: I’m in the EDL for one reason.

2070.35.text:
if I somehow say well I’m not gonna go through that area
then to me I’ve surrendered to them,

2075.52.text: I’ve, you know what I mean?

2076.81.text:
I’m fighting this cause, with everyone else,
if I turn round

2080.28.text: I’m walking down that road but I’m not walking down that road,

2082.40.text: that seems to me that I’m giving in to them.

2101.52.text: Yeah long story, very short. I was erm at the demo obviously.

2103.52.text: I travelled across with Coventry and Birmingham lads

2105.92.text: and there was some Walsall lads there as well.

2107.59.text:
I looked down to the right
and I just seen lines of police officers in riot gear

2111.07.text: and I thought ‘right we are here again, we are not getting out of this one for ages’.

2114.12.text: So I did walk down to them and I said to them,

2115.93.text:
can’t remember the exact words but it was on the lines of
‘we aren’t getting kettled in again are we mate?’

2123.65.text: and he’s gone ‘no, no ,no’ he said ‘we are just blocking the street off’.

2127.04.text: Noticed a load of guys with pink hair and multi-coloured hair shouting things,

2129.94.text: said nothing to um, walked back up, said to my mate

2135.17.text: won’t give his proper name, ‘f-ing UAF down there again ain’t there,

2143.02.text: cheeky gits after what they have done in Walthamstow

2145.33.text: occupying where we was meant to be and pelting Tommy Robinson

2147.49.text:
and all the rest of it and stewards with stones
and bricks and anything they can get their hands on’.

2151.02.text: Next thing you know I’ve looked and there’s about hundred lads down there

2155.24.text: kicking off at the police, so I’ve gone down

2157.13.text: and I’ve noticed one of the lads from Walsall and he was like looking really aggressive.

2160.85.text: So I’ve gone in front of him, tried stopping him,

2167.13.text: noticed to the right hand side there was a load of lads

2169.40.text: ripping up everything they could and throwing it at the police.

2172.32.text: Truthfully I can look you in the eye and tell you I had nothing to do with it.

2176.16.text: You know my little daughter, on her life I had nothing to do with it.

2178.90.text: So obviously I’ve got my back to 3 lines of police,

2181.87.text: the next thing you know I’ve had a baton across my shoulder,

2184.88.text: I’ve had another baton, this is police batons obviously, across my leg.

2189.70.text: I’ve gone to the floor and I’m not the only one.

2191.54.text: As we are trying to like get up everybody’s gripping each other

2194.66.text: to try and get up so it’s almost like being on a merry-go-round,

2197.26.text: you can’t, and next thing you know I’ve got one on my head.

2201.77.text: and was took through what looked like a big steel cage sort of thing

2205.21.text: and there was like what we know as ‘paddy wagons’ in this country,

2209.70.text: like a big police van with loads of individual cells inside there and that was it.

2216.63.text:
I ended up in Walsall, erm Bloxwich police station,
20 hours later I was released on police bail.

2222.74.text: the police bail was to not attend EDL demos

2227.18.text: and to sign on at police station every Wednesday and every Saturday

2232.04.text: between the hours of 1 and 3 and I was banned from going to Walsall.

2238.21.text: unless, well this is the ironic thing,

2240.24.text: I’m still banned from going to Walsall

2241.83.text: but my next appearance at the police station cause they’ve re-bailed me is at Walsall.

2246.30.text:
So what are they planning to do,
have me for breaking police bail once I go in there?

2254.67.text: they haven’t found any evidence to charge me with anything.

2256.71.text: So my solicitor has said to me ‘look out if they don’t find what they are after….’

2262.39.text: cause initially they arrested me and they was looking to try and charge me

2266.15.text:
on instigating the riot,
oh yeah causing the riot and throwing missiles at police officers.

2273.40.text: I can look you straight in the eye and look straight in the camera I did not do that,

2275.98.text: I’ve never done that and I never will do that.

2277.63.text: I mean I’ve been, and Hilary’s been around me a few times,

2280.62.text:
you’ve seen me angry and shouting and but never to the point
where I’m gonna lose the plot.

2284.42.text: I’ve got too much to lose by doing that.

2286.35.text: My mortgage would go cause my missus would be out on the street

2289.29.text: if I went to prison, my business would fold

2308.69.text: Our aim in conducting this research  has been neither to support nor condemn

2312.00.text: the views expressed by the EDL.

2313.95.text: It has been rather to listen to voices of individual members within the movement

2318.53.text: and to understand rather than judge the meanings they attach to their activism.

2325.44.text: For some this very act of listening will still feel like a legitimation of those views.

2329.27.text: I would argue though that, in practice,

2331.36.text:
not listening simply reinforces that sense of being silenced
EDL members already perceive.

2339.86.text:
In this sense the more they are silenced, 
the louder they will have to shout to be heard.

2344.94.text: So what is the role of the academic here?

2347.08.text: I think it is not to use the knowledge gained to either support or condemn

2352.23.text: any particular political position but to encourage society to engage in critical reflection.

2357.65.text: To do that, we must first be self-critical and challenge our own positionalities;

2362.17.text: something which ethnography forces us to do on a daily basis.

2368.18.text:
As one respondent said as I explained to him
that I was a researcher rather than an EDL supporter,

2373.68.text: ‘Universities are the training ground of the UAF’.

2376.82.text: Does this somehow evade the responsibility of the researcher

2379.87.text: to take up a stance in relation to his/her research subject?

2382.82.text: I would argue, on the contrary,

2385.00.text: that this critical reflection itself constitutes such a stance

2389.16.text: because the problem we are addressing here is not the EDL per se

2393.17.text: but a political system that fails to engage in a listening practice

2397.04.text: and whose only response to unwelcome voices is to quote ‘to smash the fash’.

2405.13.text: is one of resistance to the replacement of explanation by condemnation.

2415.36.text:
I then realised that marching through the streets saying, 
‘Allah, Allah, who the f*** is Allah?’,

2419.80.text:
what we were actually doing was giving any moderates, 
any people who are willing to speak up against extremist voices,

2425.28.text:
we’re actually giving them something to align themselves with extremists 
on the same issue because we are offending all of them.

2433.64.text:
So to solve the problem, we need the support and we need to work 
with Muslims in this country, to defeat Islamist ideology.
